'the slopes down to 'the Quilo and Chikapa we had an
opportunity `of viewing 'the geological structure `of 'the country

A capping `of ferruginous conglomerate whwhich in many
parts looks as if it had been melted for the
rounded nodules resemble masses in slag and they
have a smooth seal on 'the surface but it is in all
probability it is an aqueous rock deposit
for it contains water worn pebbles of all sorts &
generally small, below this mass lies a pale
red hardened sandstone and beneath that a trap resembling
? whinstone The lowest `of all lies a course grained
sandstone containing a few pebbles and in con-
nection with it a white rock resembling limestone
is reasonably met with ^ and so are
banks of
loose round
quartz pebbles The banks
slopes are to longer from 'the level country above
'the further we go eastward and everywhere we meet
with circumscribed bogs ˄ on them surrounded by clumps `of
straight lofty evergreen trees whwhich look extremely
graceful on a ground `of yellowish grass. Several
`of these bogs pour forth a solution `of iron whwhich
exhibits on its surface 'the prismatic colours

On leaving 'the Moamba 'the level plateau The level plateaus
between the
rivers both
East & West
of the Moamba
across whwhich we travelled to 'the next river wasere less
woody than the slopes river glens over whwhich we had passed The trees ˄ on them are
scraggy and widely apart There are ˄ also two large
open grass covered spaces with scarcely even a bush

On these rather dreary intervals between 'the rivers
it was impossible for me not to be painfully
struck with 'the absence `of all animal life not
a bird was to be seen except occassionally a

Par.Paragraph on 'the way. / Cabango is 'the dwelling place of Muan-
Zanza Muanzanza one `of Matiamvo's subordinate chiefs - his
village consists `of about 200 huts and ten or twelve
square wattle and daub houses constructed
of poles with
grass inter-
woven The latter are
occupied by ambac half breed Portuguese from
Ambaca, agents for 'the Cassange traders The cold
in 'the morning was now severe ˄ to the feelings the thermometer
ranging from 58° to 60° though when protected it sometimes
standing stood as high as 64° at six A.M. When 'the sun is
well up the thermometer in 'the shade rises to 80° and
in 'the evenings it is about 78° A person having
died in ˄ this village we could transact no business
with 'the chief until 'the funeral obsequies were finished

These occupy about 4 days during whwhich there is
a constant succession `of dancing, wailing and
feasting gunsGuns are fired by day and drums
beaten by night and all 'the relatives dressed in
fantastic caps keep up 'the ceremonies with spirit
proportionate to 'the amount `of beer & beef expended
When there is a large
expenditure Thethe remark is often made afterwards "What a
fine funeral that was"! A figure consisting
chiefly `of feathers and beads is paraded on these
occasions and seems to be regarded as an idol

Having met with an accident to one of my
eyes by a blow from a branch in passing through
a forest I remained some days here endeavouring
though with much pain to draw a sketch of 'the
country thus far to be sent back to Mr Gabriel
at Loanda I was ˄ always anxious to transmit an
account `of my discoveries on every possible occasion
lest ˄ any thing happening in 'the country to whwhich I was going they should be entirely
lost I also fondly expected a packet of
letters ˄ & papers from whwhich my good angel at Loanda would
be sure to send if they came to hand but I

X If the reader remembers the way in which
II I was led when engaged teaching the Bakwains
to engage incommence exploration, he will detect the
hand of Providence - Anterior to that we
˄ when Mr Moffat began to give the Bible - the
magna charta of all the rights & privelegesprivileges
of modern civilisation, to the Bechuanas
Sebituane went North and introduced
the language into which he was translating
it into a new region larger than France
He at the same time rooted out hordes
of bloody savages among whom
no white man could have gone
22 a without leaving his skull to ornament
some village - Sebituane opened up
the way for me, let us hope also
for the bible - Then I was labouring
at Kolobeng seeing only such a small
arc of the cycle of Providence that
I could not understand it & felt
inclined to ascribe our prolonged
droughts to the devil, but when
forced by these and the Boers to
turn explorer - to open a new country
in the North rather than turn my
face southwards where missionaries
are not needed - The unseen hand
is again felt, The gracious spirit
God influences the minds
